content:encoded:
I recently came across an article by Chris Samiullah about How to Deploy Machine Learning Models and I was glad to observe a fair amount of overlap with the engineering practices an infrastructure we built at Helixa.

With the advancements of the state-of-the-art of Machine Learning and the vast number of available cloud services, in particular serverless architectures, the role of a Data Science team is shifting from researching novel solutions to open problems in making algorithms robust and operational.

I would like to share with you the second part of a talk “Tech Leader’s Guide to Effective Building of Machine Learning Products” I have given a few months ago at the Machine Learning for the Enterprise International Conference 2019 held in Rome by Technology Transfer.

Since then there are a few advancements that we introduced that are left for dedicated future articles, such as:

  • A Feature Store for versioning features, labels, training/inference data, and predictions
  • A logical data warehouse (built with Glue + Athena) to consistently combine the artifacts produced by batch pipeline jobs
  • The monitoring, evaluation, and explainability dashboard for trained machine learning models
  • A cache for speeding-up, and saving costs, with external data enrichment APIs

Meanwhile, you can enjoy the guide for tech leaders in the following slide deck:

I have 3 questions for you:

  1. What are the unaddressed challenges of transitioning from research to production?
  2. Have you experimented with better practices/tools than the ones described above?
  3. What is your experience with serverless technologies applied to machine learning?

***

You can also read about the first part, the Manager’s Guide to Effective Building of ML Products, and the introductory article 5 Steps to Understand and Implement Machine Learning on the Helixa blog.

The post The engineering practices and serveless architectures every AI product team should know appeared first on Vademecum of Practical Data Science.
